awd_titl_txt: EAR-PF: Investigating the effects of bedrock dip angle on knickpoint morphology and evolution via flume experimentation and numerical modeling
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Kristin Chilton has been awarded an NSF EAR Postdoctoral Fellowship to investigate how the orientation of rock fractures (cracks) in river beds influences the ease with which that rock is eroded (worn away) by flowing over waterfalls (also called knickpoints).  Knickpoints are often zones of concentrated erosion within rivers and this project will involve creatively designed experiments that examine the role of cracks in controlling river erosion into rock.  The results of this study will allow scientists to better predict how Earth’s surface will change over time, interpret climatic and geologic histories from the landscapes we see today, and improve engineering designs for the safety and longevity of important infrastructure. The work will be carried out at Virginia Tech and West Virginia University in collaboration with mentors, Dr. Kyle Strom and Dr. Charles Shobe, respectively. Dr. Chilton’s project will also provide opportunities for undergraduate involvement in academic research, support diversity in STEM fields through summer outreach programs, and introduce a broader audience to Earth science topics via educational videos and blog posts focused on river erosion processes. 

The primary goal of this project is to test how the orientation of discontinuities (which can be fractures, joints, or bedding planes) influences hydraulic plucking of bedrock blocks within knickpoints, and therefore knickpoint morphology and evolution. This will be accomplished via a series of flume experiments, which will use stacked porcelain tiles to simulate layered sedimentary bedrock at various dip orientations, coupled with continuous monitoring of knickpoint morphology, retreat rate, and plucking events. The results of the flume experiments will then be integrated into numerical landscape evolution models to expand implications to broader spatial and temporal scales. This investigation will fill a critical gap in our understanding of the fundamental controls on bedrock channel morphology and fluvial incision processes, improve robustness of landscape evolution models by incorporating specific bedrock characteristics, and help ensure appropriate interpretation of knickpoints as indicators of climatic and uplift history by characterizing a potential control on knickpoint form and celerity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Erosion of bedrock within rivers is one of the most important processes that shapes the surface of the earth. When bedrock rivers erode into their beds, the surrounding hillslopes steepen and begin to fail, and the entire surrounding landscape eventually is lowered. Over long timescales, these processes sculpt beautiful landscapes, but over short timescales, they can dramatically impact critical infrastructure like dam spillways, bridges, and roads.

The rate, pattern, and mechanisms of bedrock river erosion are significantly impacted by the characteristics of the underlying bedrock. We focused on understanding how erosion processes and river morphology are impacted by a specific characteristic of the bedrock – the orientation of the discontinuities (e.g., fractures, sedimentary bedding planes) in the rock relative to streamflow direction. To do this, we conducted flume experiments that simulate river erosion through bedrock with discontinuities oriented upstream, downstream, and horizontally. We discovered that the rock is most erodible when discontinuities are oriented horizontally, and least erodible when they are inclined upstream. We also discovered that discontinuity orientation impacts river evolution in other, more complex ways, also influencing the shape of the river bed, the flow structure, and the bed-armoring behavior of eroded and redeposited material. These results suggest that portions of geologically-complex landscapes may evolve differently than neighboring regions as the dominant discontinuity orientation varies, and that dam spillways surrounded by horizontal or downstream-oriented bedrock may be particularly susceptible to erosion.

By studying the relationship between bedrock characteristics and river erosion processes, we have not only learned more about how rivers can shape landscapes over long timescales, but have also gained practical insight into the factors which may cause dam spillways and other critical infrastructure near rivers to be more susceptible to erosion.
